name: History of Design Timeline
value: Course map from the 1851 Great Exhibition to Postmodernism (D3 Tree Node format).

children.name: 1851 / 1851 Britain Industrialization — Great Exhibition
children.value: Industrial-era exhibition culture; mass production meets spectacle and display.

children.name: The Crystal Palace (Joseph Paxton)
children.value: Prefabricated iron-and-glass exhibition hall built for the Great Exhibition.

children.name: Osler 'Crystal Fountain' (F. & C. Osler)
children.value: Large glass fountain shown at the Great Exhibition; symbol of industrial craft + display.

children.name: Coalbrookdale 'Boy and Swan' Fountain (cast iron)
children.value: Cast-iron fountain produced for the Great Exhibition; industrial material as ornament.

children.name: 1851-1890 / Design Reform
children.value: Reformers react to industrialization: honesty in materials, craft revival, design education.

children.name: Red House (William Morris + Philip Webb)
children.value: Arts & Crafts landmark; collaborative architecture + interiors emphasizing handmade craft.

children.name: Trellis wallpaper (William Morris)
children.value: Morris’s first wallpaper design; nature + pattern as a critique of industrial taste.

children.name: Diamond-shaped teapot (Christopher Dresser)
children.value: Industrial-era product design bridging craft aesthetics and modern manufacturing.

children.name: 1890-1914 / Art Nouveau
children.value: Total design: flowing lines, nature motifs, new materials, and unified visual worlds.

children.name: Gismonda poster (Alphonse Mucha)
children.value: Iconic poster style that helped define Art Nouveau graphic design.

children.name: Paris Métro entrances (Hector Guimard)
children.value: Urban infrastructure turned into ornament; signature whiplash forms.

children.name: Dragonfly table lamp (Tiffany Studios / Clara Driscoll)
children.value: Stained-glass lighting as luxury craft object within Art Nouveau domestic interiors.

children.name: 1919-1933 / Modernism and Bauhaus
children.value: Functionalism + new pedagogy: art/industry integration, standardization, and clarity.

children.name: Wassily Chair (Marcel Breuer)
children.value: Tubular-steel furniture; machine aesthetics + lightweight structure.

children.name: Bauhaus Building, Dessau (Walter Gropius)
children.value: Modern school building: glass curtain wall + rational plan for new design education.

children.name: Barcelona Chair (Mies van der Rohe + Lilly Reich)
children.value: Modernist furniture icon; luxury materials with minimal form.

children.name: 1920-1939 / Art Deco
children.value: Geometric glamour, luxury materials, and modern imagery shaped by global exchange.

children.name: Bibendum Chair (Eileen Gray)
children.value: Modern lounge chair with playful volumetric upholstery; high-end modern interior culture.

children.name: Bacchantes Vase (René Lalique)
children.value: Decorative glass object exemplifying Art Deco sensual geometry and material finish.

children.name: Chrysler Building (William Van Alen)
children.value: Skyscraper as Art Deco monument; ornament, speed, and corporate identity.

children.name: 1925-1940 / American Art Deco
children.value: Art Deco translated into U.S. mass urbanism: skyscrapers, interiors, public works.

children.name: Empire State Building (Shreve, Lamb & Harmon)
children.value: Art Deco skyscraper icon; verticality + spectacle in the Depression-era city.

children.name: 30 Rockefeller Plaza / RCA Building (Raymond Hood et al.)
children.value: Art Deco corporate modernity; integrated media/commerce complex centerpiece.

children.name: Golden Gate Bridge (Joseph Strauss + Irving Morrow detailing)
children.value: Engineering monument with Art Deco design language and civic symbolism.

children.name: 1930-1955 / American Streamlining
children.value: Aerodynamics as style: speed lines, smooth shells, and optimistic technological form.

children.name: Chrysler Airflow (automobile)
children.value: Early U.S. production car shaped by streamlining research and modern engineering ideals.

children.name: Pioneer Zephyr / Burlington Zephyr (streamliner train)
children.value: Stainless-steel streamliner; speed + efficiency as public image for transport.

children.name: Studebaker Commander Starliner (Loewy Associates / Robert Bourke)
children.value: Low-slung coupe; postwar streamline/jet-age cues shaping American car identity.

children.name: 1945-1970 / Postwar and Pop
children.value: Postwar prosperity + consumer culture: modern living, mass products, pop imagery.

children.name: Eames Lounge Chair and Ottoman (Charles & Ray Eames)
children.value: High-comfort modern furniture; industrial methods + domestic luxury.

children.name: Pocket Radio T3 (Dieter Rams, Braun)
children.value: Minimal, rational industrial design; everyday electronics as modern lifestyle objects.

children.name: Campbell's Soup Cans (Andy Warhol)
children.value: Pop Art landmark: branding and repetition as a critique/celebration of mass culture.

children.name: 1970-1995 / Postmodernism
children.value: Reaction to strict modernism: quotation, irony, pluralism, and playful form.

children.name: Piazza d'Italia, New Orleans (Charles Moore)
children.value: Architectural quotation + theatrical public space; postmodern urban symbolism.

children.name: Carlton Room Divider (Ettore Sottsass / Memphis)
children.value: Memphis icon: bold geometry and laminate color as anti-functional statement.

children.name: Alessi 9093 Kettle (Michael Graves)
children.value: Postmodern product design: playful ornament and pop references in an everyday object.
